summary: Simba idolizes his father, King Mufasa, and takes to heart his own royal destiny on the plains of Africa. But not everyone in the kingdom celebrates the new cub's arrival. Scar, Mufasa's brother -- and former heir to the throne -- has plans of his own. The battle for Pride Rock is soon ravaged with betrayal, tragedy and drama, ultimately resulting in Simba's exile. Now, with help from a curious pair of newfound friends, Simba must figure out how to grow up and take back what is rightfully his.

The Lion King (2019) is a film that looks beautiful but falls short in terms of its soul and heart. The acting is alright, but it feels like the actors were just doing imitations of the original characters, with nothing special added. The pacing is slow, and the film takes out some of the best parts of the original. It is a fun film to watch, but if you have access to the original, I highly recommend watching that instead. The story, characters and the overall feel of the original is much more engaging and meaningful. The animation is impressive but the story and emotions are not as good as the original. Overall, The Lion King (2019) is a decent film, but it falls short in comparison to the original. I give it a 6 out of 10.

A soulless tech demo.
Obviously, it looks pretty good, I'm sure when it came out 3 years ago it looked amazing.
But it's misguided to a degree that is almost impossible to comprehent. They turned a cartoony animated movie and story into something resembeling life action.
Why? For what purpose? If it was a re-imagining, where they took the basic premisse of the story and turned it into something that benefited narratively from looking more realistic, then that would be fine.
But they took the same skript, the same story (a skript and story that, to make it clear again, was made for a cartoony animated feature) and then just... turned up the "realism".
Which results in "realistic" animals that have no facial expressions and move like real animals... but behave in the context of the story like no animal would.
Some people like it because it looks realistic, but so far I haven't seen anybody explain what the story actually GAINS from looking like this. While it's very, very obvious what it LOSES. It loses character, it loses emotions. It loses so much of what made the original so great. Without gaining anything.

If you want to be baffled by some impressive tech demo, then... sure, watch it. Or maybe watch the trailer and some individual scenes, because no tech demo should be 2 hours long.
If you want to see this story, told competently, with characters and moments that will stick with you for decades... go back and watch the original. It's timeless and still worth a watch, even if you haven't grown up with it.

Watching this visually more of a live action type film (although it is primarily filmed using CGI but appears more like a live action film),  it brought back old memories of the original cartoon version - nice memories, thankfully. The themes of loss and self identity are timeless ones and the whole 'Circle of Life'  aspect is somewhat poignant at the moment too (this review dates from March 2020). The cinematography I thought was undoubtedly impressive and I very much appreciated seeing it in the Blu-Ray format - in these days of lowering numbers of new films being released in the Blu-Ray format, I'm glad this one was. The voice acting/vocal performances are also quite impressive. I enjoyed it as an adult watching it, with nostalgia for the original version, which was released when I was in my tween years (I think I was about 12 when it came out in the mid 1990s). I would definitely recommend this film to fans of the original, if your ok with the idea of a live action version of this, like the (also recent) live action/CGI version of The Jungle Book. If CGI doesn't appeal to you, then you may not be so impressed but that goes without saying.

The only other thing I'd like to add is that if your considering this to show to young kids, I would warn that some scenes could be reasonably frightening to very young kids, due to the nature of the scenes - the themes present, i.e. death, fighting etc. Violence is certainly implied, although I wouldn't say its full of bloody violence as such but very young kids probably would be better with the cartoon version, hence the PG rating this film has been given in the UK. At a rough guess, I'd say kids maybe around about 8 or 9 or older should be ok with this, in my opinion.

Disney took everything that made the 1994 animated movie and turned into a CG "Live Action" mess. People are calling this live action, but it is a computer animated film that removes the character, charm and emotion shown so brilliantly in the hand-drawn animated masterpiece. Also, it is a musical, however they managed to ruin the music by just shoving the familiar pieces into scenes they were not meant to be in, just for the sake of nostalgia. They gave the roles to mostly untalented people, celebrities or actors who either couldn't sing or act, or both. They brought back James Earl Jones to play Mufasa, but he has lost the power in his voice to really make the character shine like in 1994. Now he just sounds like an old geezer, and they even placed unused clips/takes from the 1994 movie in place of some scenes in this 2019 movie. Again, they brought back James Earl Jones, but didn't bring back Jeremy Irons as Scar, who is easily one of the best performed characters and Disney villains in history. Makes completely no sense. The director picked and chose what would be in this movie, which was intended to be "like a documentary" and "be more realistic" in a movie that featured talking and singing  animals. The only reason this movie did so well at the box office is because of the nostalgia factor, but ultimately is no match for the 1994 animated classic in terms of quality. If you want to watch a good version of this movie, watch the 1994 movie and don't buy into these Disney cash grabs which just want to siphon money from you because it reminded you of your childhood.

The Lion King (2019) continues the trend of Disney remaking all of their older properties and similarly, removes the heart and soul of what made the original so memorable. Obviously, with the attempt at realism, the movie removes facial expressions which hurts any scenes meant to be "emotional" and calls on the audience to do the HEAVY lifting of remembering the original to fill in the absolute emotional gaps this movie leaves in its wake. On top of all that, the themes and story of the movie aren't even much of a change as much of the movie is a shot for shot remake with the only changes provided serving more of a detriment than anything else. The themes communicated in the original film are essentially wiped away in this film with some scenes even being removed and some effects not being able to be shown because of "realism." With time, this movie's effects will begin to age like yogurt but that won't matter because this movie made far far too much money for Disney to care.

1994's 'The Lion King' is not just one of my favourite Disney films, it is also one of my favourite animated films and one of my favourites overall. Beautiful animation, some of Disney's most iconic songs and amazing score, an entertaining and powerful story with unforgettable moments, terrific voices (especially James Earl Jones and Jeremy Irons) and joint best beginning to a Disney film alongside 'The Hunchback of Notre Dame'.

Disney's live action films are often frowned upon, they often have been described as pointless and many feel that Disney are running out of ideas. Can totally understand this, as the small handful that have been made so far have not really been necessary but the quality of them have varied. 'Cinderella' and 'The Jungle Book' were great and by far the best of the remakes, but the rest have left me mixed. Will admit to not really seeing the point of this version and was not massively impressed by the trailer, but saw it anyway being such a fan of Disney and because my sister desperately wanted to see it. Watching it way back when it first came out but with being behind with my reviewing it took me to now to review it, it was a little better than expected and not as bad as others have said. My sister did like it a lot better than me, with my feelings being quite lukewarm. Am really trying not to compare and try and judge it on its own terms, but sometimes it is hard when the quality of a remake, follow up or another adaptation is very far removed from something so good and that is the case with comparing both 'The Lion King' films.

'The Lion King' (2019) does have good things. The best thing about it by a mile is the visuals, which are absolutely fantastic. Something of a technical achievement, with the scenery being breathtaking in every sense ("Circle of Life" being a notable example) and the characters (excepting their eyes needing more expression) blend very realistically in a way where one gets the sense that this was a nature documentary. The score is still powerful, especially in the stampede and one of Disnney's most iconic tear-jerkers. Have always loved the songs, and with two exceptions they still make an impact. "Circle of Life" is truly awe-inspiring and the closest the film came to making me cry.

Most of the dialogue has some moments of humour (Timon and Pumbaa) and tension (the hyenas). The story has its moments. Can not praise "Circle of Life" enough, Timon and Pumbaa are amusing and the stampede is intense, not goosebump-inducing though, even though everybody who has seen the original will know the outcome. Making the hyenas scarier and fleshing out the lionesses (a little) more were good moves. Actually thought that a lot of the voice work was not bad at all, Billy Eichner and Seth Rogan being so much fun and by far the best faring of the voices, they were clearly having fun too with the improvising and their comic timing is full of exuberance not obvious elsewhere. Florence Kasumba's Shenzai is very different, the opposite in fact, to Whoopi Goldberg's, and the more sinister edge worked very well. James Earl Jones, the only voice actor to reprise his role, still has Mufasa's booming dignity and Donald Glover does quite well.

Didn't care for some however. Was mixed on John Oliver, who is fun but overdoes it at times. Beyonce comes over as very out of place, her voice not fitting how Nala looks, and she even sounded bored. Chiwetel Eijofor, a good actor who was brilliant in '12 Years a Slave', was the biggest disappointment, found him too subdued for Scar and he is nowhere near as menacing or enjoys himself as much as Irons (whose voice work is some of the best for any Disney, and animated, film). While "Circle of Life", "I Just Can't Wait to be King" and "Hakuna Matata" come off well (especially "Circle of Life"), "Be Prepared" was bizarre and quite over the top, what a way to waste one of the greatest Disney villain songs. "Can You Feel the Love Tonight" was reminiscent of decent at best karaoke. "Spirit" is even worse, that did not fit within the film and was more an excuse for Beyonce to show off her vocal chops and have actually heard much better singing from her.

Excepting the hyenas being scarier, some additional dialogue and the lionesses being more fleshed out, 'The Lion King' suffers from being too faithful and not having enough of its own identity. Too many of the scenes are near-carbon copies with only fleeting moments of heart and soul, mostly the film emotionally is very bland. The big death scene, heart-wrenching before, is treated in too throwaway a fashion. The additional dialogue and any interpolations are not for the better either and actually rather jar, while the cuts and changes were not necessary. The eyes and facial expressions for the characters, especially Scar, lack nuance and are at times borderline creepy.

Summing up, found a lot to like but was disappointed overall. 6/10

While it was a visual masterpiece, it's a very basic retelling of the same story without adding anything fresh to the story plus because it's live action so none of the characters have emotions on there face which can make it a bit dull. AUDREY WU - THE LION KING 

A Reboot of the Classic - yet Terribly Trite

The Lion King is a remake of the original animated classic made in 1994; through the use of motion capture and incredible visual effects, Disney has created a stunning photorealistic film through the hefty budget of 260 million USD. Then again, that's the only thing special about this film - the visuals. Apart from that, just about every inch of this movie is exactly the same as its 1994 counterpart. 

The Lion King is a story about a young lion cub called Simba (Donald Glover) whose father is killed by his uncle, Scar (Chiwetel Ejiofor); after being cast out, he must return to save his pride, and take his rightful role as king of the Pride Lands. 
Yes, the animations are spectacular and yes, the scenes contain fresh perceptions, but the remake is just that: a remake. There's just about no originality, and no new points or characters to the plot. If you wanted to watch "the Lion King", the 2019 version really doesn't offer any upsides.
 
The one special thing about this remake, however, is of course its animation, but a "live action" reboot - without any live action at all - actually ruins a lot of the movie.
Watching lifelike animals belt out lyrics is a lot harder to stomach than animated lions. For instance, their mouths seem strange and robotic, and we just cannot suspend our disbelief. Throughout the entire movie, I found myself drifting away from the musical numbers and wishing I could've been back home instead of watching a lion cub sing the exact same songs as the original. 

In my opinion, a movie that isn't believable is a movie not worth watching. Sure, the movie's great, but the format of the animation just wasn't worth it. The original 1994 version had all of the perks and none of the disadvantages. 

If you want to enjoy this classic, why not just watch the classic? The hype of this remake is unwarranted and, in every aspect, the 1994 original is much better. If you liked the animation, just watch a Nat Geo documentary on lions. Trust me, you'll enjoy it a lot more.

The new Lion King movie is a visual treat. Beautifully animated imagery and settings. Everything looked so real, it's like they were not computer generated. I know that critics and audiences have mixed feelings about how the movie was animated, some saying that it looked like a National Geographic documentary. But personally, I think they did a great job. It's just that the characters couldn't "act" so well because they were made to look like real animals, hence they had no eyebrows and their facial expressions were limited. But with the help of a great script, direction and music, they were still able to capture the essence of the original 1994 animated film. Having a great ensemble cast of African Americans as voice actors was a great idea. It enhanced the characters with better accents and personalities. I'm glad they still got the irreplaceable James Earl Jones to voice Mufasa, but I did miss Jeremy Irons, Nathan Lane and Whoopi Goldberg. The tragic scene was still effective, though a little bit diminished. Scar was still viciously highlighted as the main villain. Timon and Pumbaa were still hilarious. I just wished they featured more songs. Overall, the first animated movie is still king, but I greatly enjoyed this new version and I think they were still able to revive the same endearing story that made us laugh and cry a few of decades ago.

I grew up having watched the original animated The Lion King movie, so when this live action adaptation was announced I was very excited for it. What I ended up getting though, was not the same movie at all. While the film looks beautiful, and I want more of Billy Eichner and Seth Rogan as Timon and Pumba, the rest of the film and its aspects really hold this one back. Out of all the films released by Disney in the live action adaption lineup, this one by far is the most disappointing so far. The film doesn't try and be something different, it tries to copy the original note for note, but misses the parts that made the original so great. The plot of The Lion King by itself is just the story of Hamlet with animals, what made The Lion King the masterpiece it was before, was the characters, color, and imaginative fun. With that gone we just have a strange retelling of Hamlet with animals. I am sure there are some people who will enjoy this film, and some who will think it is better than the original, but I am not one of those people. For families looking to see this one, I suggest playing the original animated film for your kids instead and they will get a lot more out of it.

Conclusion: I love this movie, but not as much as the original movie from 1994.

I thought the movie did very well regarding the life if a king's son, soon to be the king, finding himself after a huge setback of growing up experiencing life different than many of his kind. This movie also demonstrated how to overcome obstacles such a lies meant to ruin your name. Through the perspective of Simba, viewers were able to see how despite his insecurity of not being the king his father was, he proved that he was somebody and not a nobody. He was constantly reminded of who he was and who we was going to be as long as he was willing to fight for what he loved, even if that be for his title as king. Lion King relates a lot to the reality of how life naturally has insecurities and setbacks.

What this movie lacks in originality it more than makes up for with its out of this world visuals the detailing on the animal's fur is some of the best CGI I've seen in any movie (its especially amazing on the big screen) it almost feels like a National Geographic documentary and shows how far computer rendering technology has come unfortunatley Disney has turned one of their best movies ever into a lazy cash grab by doing a shot for shot remake despite that they still put alot of effort into researching African wildlife and making it as realistic as possible I love what they did with the hyena queen character she is much more menacing and scary than the original her fight with Nala was better than simba vs scar. scars death is even darker and more graphic than the original they actually show him being eaten alive by hyenas if only they brought back Jeremy irons to voice him. despite the fact that Disney was creativley bankrupt and chose to copy and paste the story of the original its still visually stunning and definitely worth the watch

6.75/10. This adaptation of the cartoon classic is a nearly beat-for-beat, shot-for-shot retread of it's forbearer. It feels less like a remake or re-imagining than a remaster - viewers who want a new spin on a classic will be disappointed to find they are paying to see a movie they've already seen (albeit with a new coat of paint). While it's a shame that director/producer Jon Favreau added nothing new to this tale (despite proving his capabilities with 2016's vivid and fresh 'The Jungle Book') it manages to retain the soul of the original and is sufficiently entertaining. Excellent voice and vocal performances couple with stunningly life-like depictions of wild Africa and it's animal inhabitants to satisfy fans hoping to relive an old favorite, while offering new viewers an experience approximate to what the rest of us experienced in 1994, albeit with less facially emotive animals.

The Lion King being my favorite animated Disney movie, I've watched it many times as a kid, as an adult and shared it with my kids.

When Alice in Wonderland came out, I was hoping and excited for The Lion King. More live action movies released and I know it was only a matter of time. 

This movie is fantastic. Not since Avatar have I been blown away by the visuals. Disney did such a good job on the animations, the animals move realistically, they look realistic and if animals could talk, this is how they would look while talking. A lot of people are hating on this movie to be part of the crowd, I give this 5 stars because the story wasn't changed, the CG is seriously mind blowing, the soundtrack was done in justice, it's darker than the animated original and it was pretty action filled. 

I feel this movie benefits from its live action. Scar looks more menacing, and you do get emotional and a heart warming sensation when watching because you see how an animal would actually look like when happy or sad. Maybe the negative reviews were from people who don't have any pets?

It had some elements that made me laugh that wasn't in the original movie. However, it missed the mark. Personally for me there was some audio issues with the movie. It seemed in places that the music was louder than the characters whom where speaking at the time. Credit where credit is due, the visuals are the best I have ever seen in my life! For CGI, some points I was convinced that it was real animals. It's hard to explain how it missed the mark, even though it was done beautifully. I also don't think its suitable for young kids, unlike the original movie. I feel like the realism could scare the younger generation who watch this. I wish they had updated the new film, maybe add some new scenes that wasn't in the original, and maybe a new song or two. As much as I love beyonce, I feel like she was overpowering when it came to her songs, drowning out her male counterpart in most songs. Also I didn't like how much beyonce styled the song to her, the countless of rifts in places where it should have been a simple note. I say overall if you're going to make a remake, keep it as close to the original not how this movie was made. things such as the songs and what the characters look like, should be a minimum requirement/goal. Which they did not achieve. I probably won't watch it again if I'm being honest.

What were they thinking? That's how I would sum up this film in one sentence. If you're going to reboot something then you either need to take the original and improve upon virtually every element of it, or basically rewrite the script while keeping the same basic premise. This film fails to do either of these: every song is inferior to the original version and the stage show, the script and storyline is almost the same but told by characters who have far less personality, the voice acting is average for the most part (although I quite enjoyed Scar for the alternative take on the character as more quiet and manipulative than the original) and I found myself just generally caring less about the whole thing. The elephant graveyard scene stood out in particular - the pace felt all wrong, and it somehow managed to lack in drama and suspense when compared with the original scene. In fact for the full movie I was forcing myself to watch it to the end, just in case it improved as it progresses. 

The one thing I will praise is the cgi, which is very impressive for the majority of the film. There are a few moments where a plant or something doesn't look quite right, but on the whole it's visually impressive. Sadly, this also results in everything somehow feeling more lifeless than the original film.

I would say if you really enjoyed the original Lion King then don't watch this. You'll find yourself cringing at moments which haven't been handled as well as the original, from Mufasa's death to the use of Pumba as live bait. All of it just falls flat - less humour, less emotion, less excitement, less suspense and all around a less enjoyable watch. What were they thinking?

This is the most hysterically sh** movie I think I've ever seen.
It takes away what is essential and adds what is unnecessary, while being entirely unneeded in and of itself.
The animation, or at least character models, while impressive, and UNexpressive and emotionless, rendering any emotional scene as absolutely hilarious while these blank-eyes zombie lions stare off vaguely in any given direction in order to attempt to relay SOME kind of feeling, but you could pretty much take away the eyes, noses and mouths, IE the faces, and get the exact same response.

It's laughable how empty this movie is.
It clearly exists as nothing but a tech-demo, a way of John Favreau to show you his cool new toy, and nothing else, otherwhile more effort would have been put into making this serious, emotional story...Well, serious and emotional.
At it's best, it's stupidly hysterical, at worst, it's The Lion King 2019.

Compared to the original, the 1994 version takes the cake by a LONG shot. There was NO NEED to make a remake. The only reason they did because they probably saw the original and said "Hey! That made over a billion, we can make a billion again if we do THE SAME THING. Think about it guys! It'll make A BILLION.". Yeah, this movie is just a pile of nostalgia bait to rank over another +1,000,000,000. Can't believe that I actually felt for it and saw it in theaters, it's just the same shit that people saw decades ago. Gave it a 2 because it passed the time, and the real-life styled animals looked amazing, but surprisingly I didn't sleep on this movie but slept on Avengers: Endgame (not because I didn't like it). I'm sad to say that these remade movies could potentially ruin the childhood of today's children, and that's coming from a Disney movie, hella sickening. The conclusion? Just watch the original, I mean, you could watch this version if you want to, but I wouldn't recommend it, this version is literally the original with RTX on, lmao.

Oh boy one of the worst remake. This was a clear cash grab. I had concerns from day one it was announced. But i was willing to give it a chance.  It seemed no one working on it understood or cared what made the 1994 version so good. It seemed like John Feavoru did not understand that the hyperrealist closer to real animal style does not work cause animals do not talk or sing. In one interview he said "Well in the oringal they had real animals come to the studio. Now we have YouTube." The problem with that is you do not understand the animal's behavior. At times it seemed like that was the case. The music was bland knock offs of the 1994 movie  music down to the score. Even going as far as to copy and paste the background vocals in certain parts. I just can't wait to be king was visually and musically ugly. The Stampede scene rather than be an emotional scene made me laugh. The acting was terrible. When will directors realize Beyoncé while an amazing singer can't act? The kid who played young Simba cannot act nor sing. Keep in mind. Poor James Earl Jones sounded tired and bored. Bringing him back was a mistake. The guy who played Scar did a decent job but it was poor directing. The difference between the 1994 one and the 2019 is night and day. It's clear they were trying to hold on the nostalgia while trying to do something different. You can't do one or the other with the Lion King! If you want that nostalgia here's a tip just watch the 1994 one. Its more visually stunning. has better acting, better music and you will get the nostalgia you crave. It would have been better to have the Broadway play on Disney+. Its a better retelling then this godawful remake!

6.75/10. This adaptation of the cartoon classic is a nearly beat-for-beat, shot-for-shot retread of it's forebear. It feels less like a remake or re-imagining than a remaster - viewers who want a new spin on a classic will be disappointed to find they are paying to see a movie they've already seen (albeit with a new coat of paint). While it's a shame that director/producer Jon Favreau added nothing new to this tale (despite proving his capabilities with 2016's vivid and fresh 'The Jungle Book') it manages to retain the soul of the original and is sufficiently entertaining. Excellent voice and vocal performances couple with stunningly life-like depictions of wild Africa and it's animal inhabitants to satisfy fans hoping to relive an old favorite, while offering new viewers an experience approximate to what the rest of us experienced in 1994, albeit with less facially emotive animals.

I recently saw this movie for the first time, and honestly it just really lacked life and charm and other animals. I understand that realistically lions don't have the same facial expressions we do, but due to the emphasis on making it realistic, a lot of the fun, colors, and emotions were lost. Don't get me wrong, I do think this remake did things right in certain cases. It expanded on the relationship between lions and hyenas while explaining that overhunting is what killed the pridelands under Scar's reign, so it wasn't some force of magic. However, I do feel like this movie would've done better if it didn't try to simply recreate what was already there. It's like listening to all the same lines as the original, but the voice acting now had to carry all the emotional weight required to empathize with the characters, and it wasn't enough. Visuals and  vocals really need to work with and compliment one another to create the right tones.

That said, this movie was also too long. I'm aware that most Disney movies now are around 2 hours, but this one really made me feel like I had wasted my time sitting through it because I just couldn't enjoy it.

Directed by Jon Favreau, starring Donald Glover & Beyoncé. Even under the circle of life, this seems a bit been there done that. Jon Favreau returns to direct another Disney live action after his triumphant The Jungle Book (2016). Here he uses the same technology with improvements to recreate this famous story with just CGI creations and no physical actors. This entire movie except one shot is all computer generated and for many That is the biggest accomplishment this film has done. The film is just gorgeous to look at and all the animals are designed beautifully down to their slightest movements. The problem with this movie is that these animals cannot emit real looking emotions like in the cartoon. The animals just have the same look on their face in any emotional situation they are in. The film also at times is shot for shot for the cartoon, you can actually put the scenes side by side and it looks exactly the same. The voice actors all do a good job respectfully but they need to rely on the animal technology to give their performance a full ounce of emotional depth. The movie is fun overall, But I expected so much more out of this beloved movie and instead we just got a bunch of the same.

If the 2019 Lion King didn't have the massive success of the 1994 version, it would have left no mark on the industry. The SFX aren't jaw dropping enough to make it worth the watch, and hinder the film when all we are watching are non-emoting animals tell what should be an emotional story.

Just because you can remake a movie, doesn't mean you should. But of course, if the consumer decides it wants to give money to soulless rehashes of their childhood nostalgia that is what we shall be given.

Whilst the effects in this movie are incredible, that's just about all there is to it. It was a great improvement, but I think this was the wrong story to be retold in such a way.
Characters lack facial expressions, which make it all the more harder for me to tell how they feel or sympathise with them. Scar kills Mufasa? I can't tell if he feels accomplished, guilty or indifferent as he stares down at his struggling brother.
Natural lighting does not work well with emotional stories. One colour reflects only one, or none in some cases, emotion. A lack of an atmospheric change in lighting or music makes it so that during otherwise sad and emotional scenes I sit back and watch with complete indifference because the emotion that the movie wants to give to me simply isn't there. Darker lighting during sad scenes would have sufficed, but producers of this movie must have been far too fixated on making it so realistic that nothing before it could contest.
They use subtlety in all the wrong places. Points where exaggeration was needed to reflect the atmosphere back to those watching fell short. There is a lack of colour to set the mood of many scenes, a lack of pacing in scenes that should get your heart racing, and points where the movie has been improperly executed.
When I watch Mufasa die in the original I still tear up to this day. But when watching the 2019 adaption I did not feel anything. Maybe that was because they completely cut out a part of Mufasa's line where he addresses Scar as his brother and pleads for help, instead remaking it into a line that only sounds like he is making a demand. Simba's reactions as he watches are laughable. The sense of a betrayal between two brothers was not there at all.
Whilst the technological aspects of this movie are outstanding, that's all there is to it. This does not live up to the high standards that the 1994 version has set. The hyper realistic effects strip scenes of any emotion. No emotion, no atmospheric lighting, too quick of a pace in some otherwise important scenes.
This version is hard to watch when you know the original all too well. Unless you want to admire the graphics, my advice to you would be to stick with the original.

It can't be helped to compare this to the 94' feature which is undoubtedly one of the best Disney has ever produced, possibly the cream of the renaissance crop.

I'm biased against the remakes because they have all looked so boring, save THE JUNGLE BOOK, incidentally the only other remake helmed by Favreau. That one did not rise above its originator but it had plenty of its own to offer too. 

The only positive thing I can say about this film other than a few sparse laughs is that it is quite sound, technically speaking. It's hard to not give credit to the animators, doing their damnedest to make this look like it could have been cut together from extra PLANET EARTH footage. But even that department isn't without its failures.

The biggest issue I have with the film is perhaps one of the least quantifiable, but if you watch the 94 animation and this in proximity I have little doubt you'll know what I mean. It is soulless. 

From the persistent blank expressions of animals wholly unable to show their emotion, to some absolutely horrendous line reads (just about every line from baby Simba is pathetic, with an irritating high-pitched sing-song quality to it). It seems as though even James Earl Jones was given no direction whatsoever, my guess being "you've done this before James, just go nuts". There's just no charisma between any 2 of the cast, with Timon and Pumba perhaps being the exception. They're an interesting take, though I wouldn't call it a good one. 

The music is fine, but the musical numbers on the other hand are dreck. Part of the problem of having big name vocal artists doing voices is that they almost certainly came with the caveat of having them perform the songs themselves.  Nala, for instance, only ever sings as a cub in the original. Yet here, she sings an overwrought duet of "Can you feel the love tonight?" with Donald Glover, the two lions singing about themselves.. but it isn't actually them singing? Glover does a fair enough job though he has to restrain himself. Bey on the other hand.. oh my.   

She is bringing that queen bee energy whether you want it or not. The added song
is also a solid "no thanks"

I could go on for days but It honestly isn't worth the time. Sorry y'all, this one's gonna be a skip-it.

The 2019 addition of The Lion King, directed & produced by the credible John Favreau, was a shot for shot remake of the 1994 version. The only "twist" they had was botching & cutting out notable scenes, which is clearly absurd! John Favreau has made a few decent films in the past, like Iron Man, Elf, Chef, and the remake of The Jungle Book, but it seemed like he bit off more than he can chew with this one, just feeling very uninspired, dragged out, and bland.

This is just another movie that falls under the category of a cash grab. With the popularity the movie already has, this remake made a CRAZY 1.65 billion dollars (which is only $200,000 off of what the original made) at the box office, currently ranked in the top 10 of all time. There's not really much to say about the characters or screenplay because, everything is the fucking same as the first. One of the biggest issues I had with the characters, I didn't particularly care for the voice overs as a whole, also their mouths transitions didn't match when someone tried to hit a high note or scream.

The best pieces of this film, is the cinematography & animations. The scenery is done so well, that you really feel like you're in Africa, with cutting-edge detail in everything!

Overall, If you were wanting a better look, with the same story, you'll love the film; If you went in expecting a creative twist, chances are you're going to feel the same way as me.
Inspiring, uplifting movie with a heart

Jon Favreau had done a terrific job updating the jungle book into a live-action feature in 2017, by paying tribute to the original cartoon yet expanding the story-line so that there would be something new for old viewers. So it would seem natural to have him updating another Disney animated jungle movie.

The heavily Osamu Tezuka "inspired" THE LION KING, in itself it terrific animated feature benefiting from outstanding animation amazing music and Powerful drama, didn't really seem like it needed to be remade. And the case can certainly be made that in fact it should never have been.

Pretty much everything that is good about the film already existed in the previous incarnation; the mise en scene, the music, the story-line... nothing much new is added in Jon Favreau's version. And while the BBC nature Aesthetics seemed intriguing at first, in the end we lose the expressiveness of the original animation which made the drama more potent and Powerful.

What we are left with is a pretty, yet pointless remake, that does nothing to improve on the original.

Visually this film was delicious.  I loved watching the adorable cats.  I was disappointed to learn that the movie is almost 100% CGI though.  Still, it's close to the classic story, and the music is quality.  It's hard to beat the original animated version from the 90's, but this version is a winner in my book.

It isn't bad ... however.  If you have seen the original 1994 animated version of Lion King, and you have ever watched CG, then this version of Lion King is just like watching the original cartoon.  Literally, scene by scene, at times frame by frame, all the dialog and music is exactly the same. Zero originality. They basically copied the animated version. Exactly. I don't get why they even bothered. The animated version is iconic. This is a bad copy cat. What's the point?

The Lion King 2019 is not a good movie. They just take the plot from the animated movie and just make it live action. And because this movie is live action it's like watching animal planet or some nature show. It is just weird. Like I can't go with a Lion that only eats bugs and is friend with a warthog when this movie is live action. It doesn't make sense. That lion is eating that warthog. Just watch the animated version. Not everything needs to be made into a live action movie or remade. Sometimes the original is perfectly fine and this movie is one those instances where there didn't need to be a live action lion king. Wasn't necessary and wasn't good

Remakes often fall short of the original, but this was possibly the worst I'd ever seen. So much of the budget went into stunning visuals it seemed there was nothing left for the audio and voice acting. The entire film sounded like a poorly dubbed spoof that I honestly couldn't imagine how it got released. Not just bad voice acting, not just cringeworthy song covers, but because everything sounded SO dry you'd be forgiven for thinking you were listening to a podcast rather than a movie.  If you mute the audio and put on the subtitles it'll probably improve but as it is ... I honestly could never bear to watch it again. Even my kids were bored and that's the target audience.

I feel disheartened on behalf of the art and animation crew who obviously worked incredibly hard on this, only to be let down by the audio director. I was never a huge fan of the original but I'll take that over this any day.

This film really has no purpose to exist.

Final Rating: C-

I watched this movie not really sure what to expect. I loved the original, which came out the year my oldest son was born. Because the copy was so precise, it left me wondering why bother? Why not just film the Broadway play? The audience probably would have a better reaction to something "based on" the original instead of just a copy. Some of the second half of the movie was changed up a bit. Overall, this version was enjoyable, but doesn't have the classic feel of the original. Rafiki wasn't nearly as fun and didn't have the shaman feel that the late Robert Guillaume gave to the original. Like with any CGI rendering of a live being, the facial expressions of the animals weren't as effective as the cartoon drawn version. Scar, while quite evil, didn't have the same smarmy feel of the original. I guess in short, if you judge it by the original, it doesn't measure up. On its own, it's better than most kids' movies these days.

To be completely fair, this was not a bad film. It was passable on its own, and it was a pleasure seeing James Earl Jones reprise his role as Mufasa. However, comparing this 2019 remake to the 1994 classic "The Lion King" is like comparing "The Force Awakens" to "A New Hope." While it does an okay job, it pales in comparison to the original. The inherent problem with Disney's recent string of remakes is that it really is a double-edged sword: if they deviate too much from the source material, the movie will be bad because it isn't a faithful adaptation. And vice versa, if they make a film that is too similar to the source material, it will be bad because it's basically the same movie. The only way Disney could stop losing creative force would be to stop making these remakes altogether, but we all know that this will not happen anytime soon. Money talks, after all, and most of these remakes have made at least a moderate profit at the box office. And that's exactly it: like all the remakes that came before and will come after it, the 2019 version of "The Lion King" is a cash-grab. It's basically the same movie, except without the heart, the spirit, or the talent of the original. The actors do fine, but their performances aren't as great as those of the cast of the 1994 original. James Earl Jones is the only actor who anywhere near lives up to the performance of the original actor -- mainly because he WAS the original actor for Mufasa. The 1994 original will always be a classic and a masterpiece. The 2019 remake does not, in any capacity, live up to the original. If you (somehow) have never seen the original, you'll probably like this one fine. But if you HAVE seen the original, and especially if you LIKE the original, I would give this one a skip.

Visually stunning, and true to the original, with a few additional scenes and fun jokes thrown in. Awesome to have the icon James Earl Jones reprise his role as Mufasa, and the rest of the cast is great too, especially Beyoncé as Nala, Scar, John Oliver as Zazu...and Pumbaa and Timon should definitely have their own buddy comedy spinoff. 

Scene after scene I found myself in awe of the beauty of the landscapes and animals, especially during Simba's travels and coming of age (and his return to Pride Rock with Beyoncé's song playing on the background), as well as the incredible fight between Scar and Simba at the end. 

Where this movie falls short is also where it excels: it stays true to the original (more so than the Aladdin remake, by comparison...which by the way, the LK remake far exceeds Aladdin remake)...but because it stays so true, what value can it add? How does it change our way of thinking? That it doesn't reinvent itself is its shortcoming, but that's okay...it doesn't try to and it doesn't have to. Now, the real litmus test is what if for a second we can edit reality and both Lion Kings came out at the same time and there was no original and no remake...which one would be better? My guess is that the the public and critics would likely pick the animated version at a ratio of 4:1 because it's so hard to psychologically discount the "original" title...but if I'm honest, what the later version loses in vivid colors it more than compensates with majestic real life lions and African landscapes...I'll pick the later version by a hair...but given it's NOT the original, it won't rate quite as high...there's something to be said in honoring the creative value of an original story.

Don't even get me started on the weird neutrality of the CGI genderless bodies and the removal of Rafiki's red bottom. Again, Disney should have mixed realistic CGI with magical theatrics to captivate the audience and bring the film to life. This is a first for me as both a Disney remake and a project in which Jon Favreau is involved: I hated it. I felt I had to watch it to the end to give a fair review, but I had several issues with it (read: with just about everything).

The voice acting was mediocre all the way around--I even felt like James Earl Jones was just calling it in.

The musical arrangements were sub par, including abridging, or should I say, completely butchering, "Be Prepared." The vocal arranging and directing was particularly bad, and the added riffs just seem like attempts to make up for that.

The rewriting of the script was done very poorly. A decent amount of lines from the original are left in, and a far greater amount of lines are just run through a thesaurus in a rather egregious manner. And how can you have a joke that literally only makes sense if you've seen the original movie??  Many parts are completely shot-for-shot, but other sequences are rather drawn out to show off what they could do with the CGI I guess, including a copycat of the ticket-out-of-the-window scene from Polar Express that includes giraffe dung ball instead of a snowball. 

There is a complete lack of storytelling and dramatic sense.  Show, don't tell. There are multiple added scenes that do nothing for the plot. 

The characters are almost completely flat, and purely rely on the fact that these are familiar characters. Random characters are added that add nothing to the plot, which apparently serve no other purpose than to have more voice parts on an extended version of the one song that wasn't originally written for the film, while at the same time lessening the emotional impact of Timon's and Pumbaa's parts of "Can You Feel the Love Tonight?"

This was like 2001: a space odyssey but it forgot to be interesting and original. The singing (other than childish gambino) was trash. Like my entire childhood was that easily gunned just because of how shit it is. And I hate how they try reinterpreting a lot of stuff like mufasa’s death scene. The fact that I had to sit in that theatre and laugh like I was some ape tells you something about that one scene alone. It is a visual mess that makes you want to will make you regret not being a blanket. Truly disgusted by the lack of ingenuity, voice projection and really the fact that Disney is just constantly wasting our time and money. I give the film a -1/10 possibly maybe lower.

Horrible. I couldn't sit still for a single scene, kept skipping to the next, and in the end, turned it off. I put aside the English version, as I didn't care for James Earl Jones' return -while all other characters were boldly replaced with worse performances- and Beyoncé's involvement. My white pet cat is more African than her. So, I checked out our own dub, since our original Lion King production was extremely well-cast. During the Disney renaissance, we had a voice director who wouldn't stop until every little detail was perfect, and it showed. I hoped for something similar here, but we were given table scraps pretending to be voice actors. They didn't care. The child actors alone.. awful. Our Lion King 2, a "quick" direct-to-video Disney sequel mind you, had fantastic child voice actors, what the snap is this..?! Timon and Pumbaa were the most tolerable, and it seems many people say this about the English dub as well. It didn't help that the dialogue came from the static faces of animal creatures that had no reason to be computer animated. Millions have been pumped into this soulless remake for no reason, though we can't say this movie didn't earn Disney a good buck. Thank you for enabling them further, audience, damnit.

Like Favreau's previous live action remake, The Jungle Book, the special effects absolutely dazzle.. but in an attempt to recreate the original nearly shot for shot, the film comes up empty in the heart department. The voice actors seem bored..and the remakes of the classic songs are almost insultingly bad..wasting the caliber of musical talent involved (knowles, glover.) Disney's recipe for success in these remakes has gone from effective (see aforementioned Jungle Book, Cinderella) to unnecessary (Beauty and the Beast, Maleficent, Aladdin, and now this.) time to get back to original stories and leave the classics in the vault.

Overall, I am one of those people who is slightly disappointed by this remake, especially by the lack of emotions coming from our leading characters.  The film realistically doesn't offer anything new or exciting as a plot.  The reasons for watching this version of the film are simply for those who wish to go down memory lane or perhaps for those who wish to introduce the touching story to a new young generation.  5.8/10 - Walkden Entertainment

This re-make was simply not for me.  As someone who strongly and profoundly was changed from my admiration for the original as an eight year-old child - and as I was in awe with all its fabulous glory, gravitas, grandeur and absolute pefection, this instead felt like a hallmark ABC re-production attempt with a deluge of mis-casted voice acting-less talent across the board to fit animation. It had top tier visual effects that are beyond beautiful to behold, and yet I felt nothing.... It hit me and stood out like a gimmicky re-creation for a cash grab, a re-imagining that betrayed the soul and I was deftly amazed at how dissapointed and empty I felt. I actually felt shame.. like perhaps it was I whom had brought some unfounded or unrealistic expectations that I should have kept and checked at the gate before entering this world once again. It had the all encompassing splended visuals but hidden under all that brilliant gloss and artificially fantastic, fabricated effort was this absence of absolutely no heart and absolutely no soul in any of its characters at all.  My favorite characters were castrated and left as rendered, life-like caricature-zombie versions of themselves. It was numbing to observe and let sink in how they seemed as empty, hollow shells or shallow echoes only of their fomer pure, once thought indelible selves. Instead of getting lost inside this magnificent and exemplary world, I instead constantly found myself getting taken out and distracted by it...  How could they have allowed for this to occur? Dropping the proverbial ball here on something this important, impactful and grandose to us as I am speaking tentatively from the perspective of a 1990's child that unabashedly loved the original. I think I am done.

The camera barely rests on any of the faces for more than a second or two because they know it looks awful with the lack of expression. Everything feels so plastic and soulless. The voice acting and musical scores aren't even in the same ballpark as the original.

It's painful to assign a low rating to such a beloved story, but ultimately the story is not why this movie is lowly rated- it's the fact that this movie exists. The technical aspects of this movie are certainly groundbreaking and impressive, but if anything it takes away from the magic of the 1994 movie and instead brings to us a tacky, copycat version. There is none of the same emotional connection to the characters that the original had because we lose the facial expressions, the cartoonish way the characters move, and the pure way it inspired the imagination. The story is still a precious one, but this movie adds nothing to improve it. The performances are mediocre and the imagery (while stunning) does not support this style of storytelling. Hand drawn animation is an art with more impact than people realize. This movie feels like an inauthentic cash grab.

This film is the definition of a mixed bag. While the animation is very nice, the rehashed score is decent, and Timon and Pumbaa are very funny, I hate some stuff in this film. The film is soulless and does nothing new to justify its existence. Also, Simba, Scar, and Mufasa are all super uninteresting. However, Zazu is the absolute worst. He has so many jokes that could get laughs, but John Oliver's voice is so bland that I swear an answering machine did the voice work. The songs are also mixed. While I enjoyed Hakuna Matata and The Circle of Life, Be Prepared and a few others were complete garbage. Also, there are only 3 scenes in this 2-hour film that seemed decent to me. The stampede was decent in that it looked nice and kept the action going. The second is Timon and Pumbaa convincing Simba to believe in the meaningless line of indifference because these are self-aware animals choosing not to be self-aware. The final and best one is The Lion Sleeps Tonight. This is the funniest, catchiest, and honestly most interesting scene in the whole film. It is the only thing truly expanded upon from the original for some reason. There are some good elements to the film, but most of it is garbage.

Lion King (2019) I felt as much as this movie looks impressive visually it misses it when it comes to hitting the emotional responses as far as comedy, sadness, or songs. The comedy was not there at all. This film skips jokes in the Original film and I never laughed. I only chuckled. This film misses the visual vibrant colors of the original film. Everything is natural pale colors. It misses it for me when it comes to the stampede scene. What this film does do is provide more drama to action scenes and context to Scar and Nola. Scar you almost feel why he is upset with why he has not come further and that his King role was taken away from him but we also see how he abused power in the Lion King more than the animated film. This film misses the emotional responses I should have like the Circle of Life or I am going to be a King. The Scar song is the one where it is the worst. The passing in this film is too quick and does not give enough time for this film to pause and breath. I did like some things like showing how Rafiki got Simba’s Hair. I thought that characters who missed it for me in this film the most were Rafiki, Zazu’s, Timon. They never hit the emotional response that I felt in the animated Lion King. Rafiki is missing his Kong Fu moves and Timon is missing the sarcasm. I do feel like the best songs in this film are the new songs during the end credits. The redone songs in this film did not hit me either. They missed the emotional response and took me out of the film. The stampede scene in this film is not as strong as the original animated film. The Animated one gives a much bigger emotional response and feels bigger in scope. The live action film feels more contained in the stampede scene. I don’t feel a sense of danger in the stampede. I was impressed seeing thin to the bones Lions in the Lion King. I think adding that Scar over hunted in this film gave it more depth because that was not clear in the animated film. The animated film made it seem like Scar scared off all the animals.

Ugh. Talking animals. You lose a lot of the magic when you go from an exaggerated cartoon to what looks like a national geographic special with a couple people talking over the scenes adding their own dialog. That one fact could not escape me. While it is a good testament to the CGI in the film... it was totally unnecessary to remake this movie. The live action look of CGI animated animals added nothing to the legacy of the lion king and if anything, further convinces me I need not bother seeing any of the other remakes they roll out. Not a fan. Do yourself a favor and watch the original one instead.

Go watch the original animated movie.

More of the same.  Like I need to describe the plot of The Lion King, but this is about the life of a lion named Simba (Donald Glover).  His father (still James Earl Jones) gets murdered under questionable circumstances, so Simba flees the kingdom, only to later learn a life lesson and assume the responsibility he previously ran away from.  I'm very quickly reaching a point that I may just be skipping these movies altogether.  I've already vowed not to see these remakes in theaters so as to not inflate box office numbers, but the more I watch of these, the more I feel like I am just making extremely poor use of my time.  I'll just cut to the chase: if you've seen the 1994 animated featured, you've already seen this movie as well, and you've seen it done better.  Look, I know I am sound like I am coming down harshly on this, and if I am being honest, there are worse live-action remakes from Disney.  But with each one of these releases, I get more and more burnt out, and they've dropped four of these in the same calendar year.  I get that the technology is there for it, and the special effects admittedly look great, but they've sucked the life out of this story to the point that I think this is soulless.  It adds nothing to the already existing movie other than 30 minutes to the runtime, so why make it?  Well, this made $1.6 billion worldwide, so I get the real "why," but for me, there just has to be more artistic integrity.  They got Jon Favreau to direct which makes total sense because of The Jungle Book, but I don't think I've seen him less inspired, and I have watched the majority of his library.  If we are getting down to brass tacks here, I think that Donald Glover is miscast as Simba.  Beyoncé is really only here to do one thing, and it feels like cheating to put James Earl Jones back in the same part. Rafiki's role is so diminished that it might as well have been cut, and John Oliver is hit or miss as Zazu (for me, it's mostly missing).  The only two people I think that walk away from this looking good is Billy Eichner and Seth Rogen as Timon and Pumbaa.  They have some honestly good chemistry together, and it felt like they were actually in the same room together when they recorded their lines.  Even though they make one too many fart jokes, they were a breath of fresh air when I was all but ready to call it quits.  Even the music is a big step down for me.  No song is done better than the original, and you have Chiwetel Ejiofor totally Shatner-ing Be Prepared.  As you may expect, it's just embarrassing, and you think that it might be the low point, but just you wait.  They had the gall to make Can You Feel the Love Tonight take place in the broad daylight.  It is completely nonsensical, and it makes it all the more apparent how little quality control Disney has in these live-action remakes.  I do give points to Eichner, Rogen and the visual effects, but I cannot give you a single reason to watch this over the original.

Why?  That is all I asked myself while watching this.  Everything felt dead.  They took what as pure gold in the original and removed all that was imperishable.  Lines were changed *just* enough so they wouldn't resonate without making the movie something new to stand on its own.  All the emotion of the movie seemed to have been drained away (I've head its because the faces couldn't be as expressive as the cartoon, but just listen to the intonation of scar's "Run away Simba, and never return!" line between the two movies and you'll see what I mean.  And the pacing was off: what should've been dramatic or urgent was drawn out, and parts that you needed a few moments to sink into were rushed over.  Oh, and the "can you feel the love tonight" scene was heartless.  I went to see this on a date and afterwards demanded we return home to watch the original that night!

Visually it was very well done. The original will always be held dear in my heart and it was the original cast voices and the emotion the animation was able to portray. I would've hoped that with a budget like this, something more original and creative could come out of it- maybe the back story of Mufasa and Scar, Or how the hyenas used to be good and part of the circle of life but then turned bad.... something from the other side. Not a complete and total copy minus a lot of the comedy that was in the original. The moments with Rafiki which I loved from the first, just fell flat in the remake. While I love John Oliver, Zazu had little presence. Billy Eichman as Timone was actually the only one who made me laugh out loud. With all the original cast members still alive, it would've been fun to have Whoopi back too! 
With that said, as much as I love Jeremy Irons as Scar, Chiwetal was outstanding and you could feel every part of his acting coming through the character, he was maybe the only stand out in this movie. All in all, enjoyable to watch from a nostalgic view, but it made me want to watch the original instead.
So, Jon Favreau - if you get another chance- get creative and start from the beginning.

The cruder, more realistic look turbines positive aspects of the animation, such as the tragic and poetic content of his narrative, which closely resembles Shakespeare's works.
The so-called "lack of expressiveness" so badly evaluated by the public and critics, from another perspective, contributes decisively to what seems to be the primordial proposal of this production: to bring to the real world this fable so true in its ability to reflect about the meaning (or cycle) of life.

2019's THE LION KING is a sight to behold visually with an excellent voice cast and great vocals/songs that are able to elevate and distance itself from the original. GOOD:
-The visual effects gorgeous, and felt like watching a nature documentary
-James Earl Jones as Mufasa was great like the original
-Seth Rogan and Billy Eichner stole the show as Pumba and Timon
-Chiwetel Ejiofor as Scar was very convincing and he took a more grounded approach that worked well
-The Hyenas were really good and held up to the originals
-Kid Simba and kid Nala gave strong performances
-Mufasa's death scene made my heart race and was well crafted and shot
-John Oliver as Zazu was solid
-John Kani as Rafiki gave a solid performance
-The jokes landed almost every time thanks to the great delivery from Rogan and Eichner  
OKAY:
-Beyonce and Donald Glover's performances as Nala and Simba, sometimes it was strong other times fell flat
-Musical numbers were okay, nothing really special
-It added nothing to the original film unlike Jungle Book which did back in 2016
BAD:
-Sometimes because the animals are so realistic emotional connection is lost and the characters lack expression

As someone that's been part of the 3D graphics scene since I got a copy of Real3D on the cover of an Amiga magazine in the 90's, I'm absolutely blown away by the graphical quality of it all. I'll give it 5 years and we'll not be able to tell a 100% CG movie from a real one! I couldn't dive into the movie as a passenger because I was constantly blown away by the tech gone into every scene. The musculoskeletal work in every creature was astounding! The physics effects of hair and fur, the water tension of the piece of fur on the river, wind effects on trees and shrubs, the fire and smoke, they all blew my mind!
It's just a pity the animators leaned more toward realism as it took away the ability to exaggerate the animal expressions in the way a cartoon animation does. If you're going to anthropomorphise animals, why limit yourself so much to realism?
My only critique is because everything was so real, it sometimes got a bit hard to keep track of who was talking before I recognised who's voice was who's, because you only see their lips moving while their body is almost perfectly mimicking what the animal would do in nature. It was almost like watching a BBC wildlife documentary with dubbed in animal voices hehe.
I still recommend it purely based on the technical marvel
I overall liked it, but it lacked some of the magic of the original film.
The effects are legitimately impressive but why and for who? All of the "realism" here just undermines the fun of the original.

The third released of Disney's 2019 nostalgic triple feature left something to be desired. Following in the impressive wake of Aladdin it was lacking in several ways. It didn't stray far enough from the blueprint to stand on it's own and several of the voice acting performances fell flat. The singing was on point, though the lyrical changes felt like steps back as opposed to upgrades. Seth Rogen definitely delivered a well "rounded" performance and was my favorite piece of the experience.

I enjoyed this film simply because it was an exact, if inferior, replica of the literally perfect original. But it just didn't need to be made. It didn't add anything (not that anyone would want it to). However, it accomplished its likely ultimate goal of getting millennials like me to throw money at it. Billy Eichner and John Oliver's voice work were highlights for me. The visuals, by virtue of being more "realistic," lacked the critical fantasy elements of the original. While they were technically impressive, the emotional weight of it was subdued. Life-like lions can't EMOTE! I needed to see Simba's TEARS after Mufasa died! 

Also, Beyonc is clearly too famous for this kind of role. She pulled me out of the whole thing every time she spoke. And it was obvious that she and Gambino recorded their voice acting and singing separately, which killed my vibe. The new song was nice, I guess, but the separate music video is more fun and visually stunning than the film.

For the script 
In terms of story, the latest version of The Lion King is exactly the same as the animated version. However, the viewing experience is completely different.

The live-action version starts with the splendor of the wild with the animals in it. The depiction of these two things coupled with the song 'Circle of Life' which is the same as the animated version managed to stun when he saw this film.

This makes the audience look forward to the next scene. But here Disney makes a number of differences even in pleasant moments that don't last long, for example when romantic moments that should appear when they sing at dusk like in the animated version feel much different in this live-action version.

Even so, this film can still make the viewer reminisce. Old songs like Hakuna Matata, I Just Can't Wait to be King, and Can You Feel the Love Tonight can still make the audience hum along.

The Lion King is another live-action remake of one of Disney's best loved animated films and it has a tough act to follow the original.  Although it doesn't quite achieve this, there's still much to enjoy this time round.
James Earl Jones returns as the voice of Mufasha and the rest of the cast do a good job in their character portrayals, although Chiwetel Ejiofor never quite manages to capture the sinister wicked voice of Scar as Jeremy Irons did in the original.
The computer generated effects are absolutely breathtaking and incredibly realistic, it's hard to believe it's not a documentary, although it is a bit of a giveaway when the animals start singing and talking.
The story is by and large faithful to the original and all the songs by Elton John and Tim Rice that played a huge part in making the original such a success are back again.

While their attempt to bring an old childhood classic back to the screen for a younger generation may be admirable, they prove the proverb "if it ain't broke, don't fix it".  The character plot changes were a let down (speaking of Scar, Rafiki, and Shenzi), none had any facial expressions and were near impossible to tell apart, even "Scar" who should stand out in the crowd, was camouflaged.  Let's not get started on the absolutely horrible casting, and I do mean horrible. The actors couldn't sing to save their lives and when they did you wished they didn't.  I had hopes for Donald Glover but his voice was trampled by Beyoncés painful wailing screams.  In addition, they removed classic scenes (Scars solo) and added new unnecessary ones (the 20 minutes of fur blowing in the wind).  At first I was excited for the new Disney remakes, now I'm hoping they'll let sleeping dogs lie.

In Aladdin, they altered the storyline slightly, and I hear The Little Mermaid plans on changing the characters to make them "more diverse"... which I hate. I want to see live action versions as close to the originals as possible.

From the musical numbers to the horrendous voice acting, I'm sure all of us could have gone without a Lion King Live Action remake. Why? Unlike Aladdin I'm not too keen on the original Lion King, however while I can respect the art in the animation - it's a huge downfall, every character has no emotion and feel robotic with their lines, music is good, animation wonderful, but the film falls completely flat. It's probably worth a watch to see photo realsitic CGI on display so fully, and Timone and Pumba once again steal the show. But it's a blatant cash grab on nostalgia with little care or love put in to it.

Terrible, just horrendous
I've never seen such a massive waste of talented actors and animators.

I honestly don't know what happened here, scenes of dialouge fly by so quickly, you'd swear you missed something, or you get stuck on nature shots for literal mintues at a time with nothing happening, not to mention cutting super important scenes, that are vital to the plot, completely out of the movie for no good reason, I'm not saying make the movie longer, god no, but cut out all that useless garbage, that was tossed in for no good reason, and give us the story we know, that's the whole point of a remake, to tell the story again, but better, or from a new angle, but it's clear they were trying to do the same as before, so just do it, we don't need all this other nonsense.

Every single line of dialouge was dead, lifeless, uninterested, or akward, not one line sounded genuine, which is amazing considering the cast. every once in awhile you'll get an okay delivery, but you could actually count it on one hand. every character sounds the same, you never get a grasp of anyones personality because they all sound the same, everyone is so monotone you'd swear you were watching the matrix.

The animation, while impressive, also has no life to it, because of the devotion to realism, everything moves slower, and the characters can't express any emotion what so ever. every character has a dead blank expression. bland awful colours filled with browns.

The animation also really affects the comedy, simply put this movie has none, because of the realism the characters aren't allowed to move in fun ways, and everyone is slowed down to a crawl, because it would break said realism, and when it does attempt physical comedy it fails horribly because all you're thinking about is an animal getting hurt, which unless you are a total psycho, is not funny, meaning all the comedy has to come from spoken lines, jokes, quips, etc. Which, while not ideal could still work, but as stated before none of the line delivery is good, and even those that have voice acting experience like Seth Rogen or J.E.J., are too distracting because, it's Seth Rogen, and that's all you are ever going hear. and honestly James E.J. is 88, and probably didn't even want to do it, and only did it because of rapid fans, so the result is exactly what you'd expect, a phoned in performance, which coincidentally is exactly what 80% of the cast probably did aswell, because it's The Lion King and they knew it was going to make money no matter what.

The music ranges from okay to awful, that is when they actually sing, or don't cut songs short, Be Prepared suffered the most, as not one line of the song is actually sung, it's just talked to a beat, and is a full minute shorter than it's supposed to be, Circle of Life is probably the only song not to suffer from the touch of death this movie oozes out of every nook and cranny, mostly because they re-use the instrumental from the original song and simply had someone re-sing it again, and from a visual standpoint it's also god awful, there's no spectacle to these songs it's just animals walking, or even standing as still as statues, to music it's boring and uninteresting to look at.

Comparing it to the original, better reviewers than I have said "I don't have the wherewithal to judge this, because I'm not it's target audience" and "Reboots/remakes don't warrant as much outrage as they illicit becasue they don't, and can't, impede your ability to enjoy the original/source material." these are valid arguements, but, what was so great about the original is that it COULD be enjoyed by both kids and adults, it's what Disney was so good at doing, and for the second point, it's a shame to see something that you cared so strongly about being utterly exploited and stripped of it's dignity, and left out in the desert to die.

These Disney remakes are not a good thing, not for Disney as a company, and not for what once was the leader in creative, and imaginitive story telling, I hate how complacent people are to these things, that they make money, and I feel bad for kids, who grow up watching these terrible Disney remakes, I hope more people wake up to how bad these things are, I know mostalgia is powerful emotion, but it's no excuse to blindy clap and declare these things masterpieces, because if they didn't have that already established fanbase, you'd no doubt say that they're awful or just okay.
I would have loved for these movies to be good, and enjoyable, and clever, and had some of that Disney magic put into them, or even be so bad that they're good, or even fun to mock, but none of these terrible live action remakes, even come close to that, and this one is the king.

Review:
‘The Lion King' is a musical-family film directed and produced by Jon Favreau. It is a photorealistic remake of Disney's traditionally animated film of the same name. 
This movie has a classic case of rehashing the same story scene by scene with some dialogue changed up. Sometimes it worked, but more then often it didn't. It messed with a lot of the classic things we all know and love from the original Lion King, tweaked them into something new, but in the end never really pulled it off.
I was really missing Jeremy Irons as Scar; Chiwetel Ejiofor just didn't bring anything to this character at all. He didn't seem menacing or scary for that matter. I remember watching the original movie and knowing that Scar is a villain that could get away with anything, and it was because of the voice acting done by Jeremy Irons. The only highlight in my opinion is Seth Rogen and Billy Eichner. Other than those two, it is a very forgettable and hollow version of the story.
First let's start off with what I liked about the movie. The CGI. It is incredible, it's mesmerising and beautiful. But that's all it is, is beautiful CGI, they've completely lost sight of the story, the emotion and the magic. There is a lot of people that complain that the animals are too realistic, so they can't capture the raw emotion of the characters like you could in the 1994 Lion King. I don't believe that to be true. You can make things lack emotion psychically because they're a realistic looking animal, but it is then the actor portraying that character's job to bring the emotion to it. Unfortunately, not a lot could pull that off in this movie.
Overall, this movie was one that I was really looking forward to and it let me down. The voice acting is forgettable almost as much as the story itself. I wouldn't be choosing this one over the original version to watch.
2.5/5
